Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Defining Structural Features of C. elegans histone H2A Variants Important for Transcriptional Regulation in Different Cell Types

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Different types of cells rely on the expression of distinct sets of genes for their development and function. Altering the accessibility of different sets of genes is one way genes can be regulated. The accessibility of genes can rely on incorporating histone H2A variants into the nucleosomes that compact DNA. For example, C. elegans express H2A variants that include the evolutionarily conserved H2A.Z (HTZ-1) and the sperm-specific HTAS-1. This project will test the hypothesis that structural differences in HTZ-1 and HTAS-1 alter DNA accessibility to regulate gene expression in a cell-type specific manner. First, biophysical approaches will define structural properties of C. elegans H2A proteins. Second, fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) and biochemical approaches will identify differences in the stability, DNA unwrapping, and packing of nucleosomes containing H2A, HTZ-1, and HTAS-1. Cytological assays conducted in genetic mutants will correlate how H2A variant incorporation affects gene expression. Swapping domains of HTZ-1 and HTAS-1 with H2A in vitro and in vivo will identify structural domains of these H2A variants that are important for their incorporation and roles in transcription in distinct cell types. Overall, these studies will elucidate the structural properties of C. elegans histone H2A variants that contribute to the specification of different cell types.

Broader Impacts: The research will be conducted at San Francisco State University, a historically minority-serving public institution. Undergraduate and master's students from the Biology and Chemistry and Biochemistry programs will be trained by the PI and her collaborators at SFSU and UCSF in the theory and practice of biochemical, biophysical, and molecular genetic methodology to understand fundamental aspects of DNA organization and transcriptional regulation. Students will work in cohorts to share resources, ideas, and expertise. Under the supervision of the PI, students will learn to critically evaluate scientific research, plan experiments, and interpret experimental data to become independent critical thinkers. The interdisciplinary training and mentorship provided by the proposed work will provide a strong foundation to advance the education and careers of SFSU's diverse students in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Our work characterized histone variant dynamics before and after fertilization. Our study in PLoS Genetics identified novel and conserved features of paternal chromatin that are written during spermatogenesis and read in the embryo. We produced one of the most extensive catalog of histone post-translational modifications (PTMs) and variant composition in sperm and embryos in any organism. We showed sperm repackage chromatin by incorporating the sperm-specific H2A HTAS-1, erasing histone acetylation globally, and retaining histone methylation at active genes during spermatogenesis. After fertilization, paternal and maternal chromatin are distinct: HTAS-1 and 6 paternal histone PTMs are retained. The project also provided preliminary findings on the expression and incorporation during development of a variant of H2A, HIS-35, that varies by only 1 amino acid from canonical H2A. HTAS-1, HTZ-1, and HIS-35 show distinct profiles of erasure and zygotic expression and incorporation at distinct genomic locations during development Our results show that different species use conserved mechanisms to reprogram epigenetic information.  

In collaboration with the Narlikar (UCSF) and Esquerra (SFSU) labs, we determined how H2A variants differentially alter nucleosome properties that impart cell-type specific functions. HTZ-1, HTAS-1 and C. elegans core histones were expressed in bacteria and reconstituted to form nucleosomes. Using FRET, we found HTZ-1 stabilizes nucleosomes compared to H2A, suggesting that HTZ-1 incorporation itself does not promote nucleosome loss. However, HTZ-1 increases DNA unwrapping. We defined a region of HTZ-1 that uncouples nucleosome stability from DNA accessibility, suggesting HTZ-1 functions in transcriptional activation by increasing DNA access without promoting histone loss. We also show, using circular dichroism, that HTZ-1 and HTAS-1 monomers and dimers have distinct structural properties compared to H2A.

Broader Impacts: From this RUI award, 11 SFSU Master’s students (7 URM) and 13 undergraduates (5 URM) received cross-disciplinary training in the Chu (SFSU Biology), Esquerra (SFSU Biochemistry), and Narlikar (UCSF Biophysics) labs. 7 students (6 URM) are now in PhD programs at UT Southwestern, UC Santa Cruz, the University of Pennsylvania, UCLA, USC, NYU, and the University of Washington Seattle. 5 students (4 URM) have jobs in biotechnology, and 2 (1 URM) are in professional schools. Students made 21 presentations at national and international meetingsBottom of Form
